image.altText: David Spears wearing a dark navy shirt sitting on a chair next to Anthony Albanese wearing a wide brimed hat

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese tells ABC's Insiders program Indigenous Australians want constitutional recognition and he is not considering other any options if the referendum fails.

title.children: PM says there'll be no constitutional recognition for Indigenous Australians if Voice fails

image.altText: A man with cap and white beard at a racing stables leans on a fence.

items.synopsis: The Office of Racing Integrity suspends Tasmania's leading greyhound trainer, Anthony Bullock, pending an investigation into conditions at his training facility.

title.children: Concerns for 91 greyhounds on property after trainer suspended pending probe

image.altText: Russell Island blaze extinguished by emergency personnel

items.synopsis: A father and five boys aged three to 11 are feared dead after fire engulfed a number of homes at Russell Island early Sunday morning. The children's mother escaped the blaze and is "terribly emotionally distressed," police said.

title.children: Five boys and their father feared dead as fire engulfs homes on Russell Island

image.altText: Two black and white out-of-focus photos of a woman, one with purple tears streaming down her face

items.synopsis: The next frontier of Australia's concussion crisis isn't on the football field, but in homes across the country, where victims of domestic violence are sustaining brain injuries at staggering rates.

title.children: Another concussion crisis is erupting — out of sight, undiagnosed and ignored

image.altText: Latisha Butt Bonny Photography

items.synopsis: While social media has long been called out for presenting narrow ideas of body image, Tamika McCall says her boudoir photography sessions are more fun and empowering, than sexy.

title.children: This photographer is combating unhealthy body image ideals on social media with boudoir imagery

image.altText: Indigenous dancers perform during a bunggul.

items.synopsis: Bungguls are the main attraction at Garma Festival, in north-east Arnhem Land. But this year is the first festival without Gumatj trailblazer Yunupiŋu.

title.children: Bungguls are one of Australia's oldest ceremonies. So, what does it involve?

image.altText: Dutch players celebrate

items.synopsis: Two more sides will qualify for the World Cup quarter-finals today. First up, the Netherlands play South Africa in Sydney, before big guns Sweden and the USA face off in Melbourne. Follow live.

title.children: Netherlands take on surprise packets South Africa in Women's World Cup

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: South Africa don't handle the corner well, Van de Donk heads low and it's saved, but it loops up for Jill Roord to knock over the line with her forehead.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 9' GOAAAL NETHERLANDS

children.content: South Africa don't handle the corner well, Van de Donk heads low and it's saved, but it loops up for Jill Roord to knock over the line with her forehead.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: For the right to play Spain in the quarter-finals.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Netherlands vs South Africa is underway in Sydney

children.content: For the right to play Spain in the quarter-finals.

image.altText: Man holding birth certificate and looking at camera

items.synopsis: Adoptee Peter Capomolla Moore wanted his father listed on his birth certificate — and after a mammoth battle with authorities, he's achieved his aim in a ruling he hopes will have implications for others in the same boat.

title.children: 'They tore up our identity': Adopted man wins six-year fight to set record straight

image.altText: A white haired dog with patches of brown nuzzles his nose into a bag filled with ice on a footpath.

items.synopsis: The United States' brutal heatwaves are particularly punishing in Arizona, where cacti are suddenly collapsing under extreme temperatures. But one city has found some creative ways to combat the heat.

title.children: Mobile cooling stations and freezing IV: The struggle for survival in America’s hottest city

image.altText: A platypus on a riverbank

items.synopsis: An ecologist says she's surprised the elusive monotremes are surviving so close to residents and urban development.

title.children: Platypuses found in Sydney's Hills District for first time in 25 years

image.altText: Victoria Police logo

items.synopsis: Three people have died from poisoning after eating mushrooms at Leongatha, in South Gippsland.

title.children: Three people dead from poisoning after eating mushrooms in Victoria's east

image.altText: A close up shot of some lottery balls.

items.synopsis: You might have heard stories about lottery winners in the US losing a big chunk of their money to taxes. But what are the rules in Australia?

title.children: How much tax do you have to pay for lottery winnings? It depends on what you do with it

image.altText: A man stands smiling next to a white domed observatory with a clear blue sky in the background.

items.synopsis: Retired mine worker Trevor Barry, who has been observing Saturn from his own backyard with the observatory he built himself, is only the second Australian to win the highest possible accolade for amateur astronomy.

title.children: How a 'pretty ordinary' bloke with a passion for Saturn is contributing to astronomy with 'first-class' research

image.altText: a queenslander, mid-rise and high-rise in a graphic

items.synopsis: You have to build up to stop building out. But can higher housing density bring about affordability?

title.children: It's one of Australia's fastest growing regions, but can we get past our 'fear of density' to house everyone?

image.altText: Kurt and his partner take selfie sitting on their bikes along a bike path

items.synopsis: With our skies crowded by planes and temperatures currently soaring in Europe, is there a way to travel without ruining the environment?

title.children: How we curbed our carbon footprint while travelling the hot European summer

image.altText: A young football fan holding an Australia scarf

items.synopsis: Can Australia's soccer industry use the World Cup momentum to grow the game domestically?

title.children: The FIFA Women's World Cup, as seen through the eyes of its youngest fans

image.altText: A satelite map of WA with red dot just north of Albany on the state's south coast.

items.synopsis: A powerful earthquake strikes just north-east of Gnowangerup, about 150 kilometres north of Albany — one of the biggest in years to hit the state.

title.children: Magnitude-5.6 earthquake rattles residents across southern Western Australia

image.altText: Main street of Ballarat with snow flakes falling down, people sitting on outdoor cafe tables with heaters, others walking.

items.synopsis: Ballarat, Victoria's third largest city, is notorious for its frosty winters and the near year-round puffer jacket uniform of its residents.

title.children: Does Ballarat deserve its reputation as the coldest city in Victoria? The answer is complex

image.altText: A Japanese striker sidefoots the ball towards goal as she runs alongside a Norway defender.

items.synopsis: A Japanese midfielder is the surprise leader in the race for the Golden Boot, Sam Kerr says yes for the Denmark game and the own goals are flying in — here are five talking points from the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Five Quick Hits — Magnificent Miyazawa does it again, Sam Kerr says yes for Denmark, and own goals top the charts

image.altText: A man in a shirt and jacket sits at a wooden table and smiles for the camera.

items.synopsis: Victorian government MP Will Fowles has rejected assault allegations after he was made to quite the parliamentary Labor Party. Premier Daniel Andrews says the matter has been referred to police.

title.children: Victorian Labor MP denies assault allegations after being made to quit the party

image.altText: Women hold up signs at a protest against an abortion ban

items.synopsis: A judge in Texas rules the state's abortion ban must allow allow exceptions for people with pregnancy complications without doctors fearing they will be criminally charged.

title.children: Texas judge rules state abortion law should allow exceptions for people with conditions 'exacerbated by pregnancy'

image.altText: Di Harcourt with her dog Sammy, in front of a black and white photo portrait of herself.

items.synopsis: When Di got the call that there was community housing with her name on it, it changed her life. A new portrait installation is helping to tell her story — and tackle stereotypes.

title.children: 'I knew in my heart this was it': Community housing offered Di stability after years of moving around

image.altText: A young Indian woman with dark hair looks at the camera. She's wearing a dark red jumper and wears a cross necklace.

items.synopsis: Juliet hopes to study medicine and become a doctor to help address the dire shortage of health professionals in Australia's regions. But her family has been waiting for eight years to gain permanent residency.

title.children: Juliet's dream is to be a doctor, but she can't afford it. She's one of thousands of our 'permanently temporary' migrants

image.altText: Dengue in Dhaka

items.synopsis: Bangladesh grapples with a record deadly outbreak of dengue fever, with hospitals struggling to make space for patients as the disease spreads rapidly in the densely-populated country.

title.children: Almost 300 dead as Bangladesh grapples with record dengue fever outbreak

image.altText: A shot of players on the court at a Netball World Cup game, with the crowd behind them, including a section of empty seats.

items.synopsis: Ticketing issues have been rife throughout the preliminary stages of the major netball tournament in Cape Town, as many question how local partner Plankton got the gig.

title.children: Aussies face ticketing dramas at Netball World Cup as questions mount

image.altText: Aerial shot of a solar farm

items.synopsis: Australia has ambitious plans to generate more than 80 per cent of its power from renewable sources by 2030. But a growing number of experts say the country is way behind where it should be.

title.children: Analysts say mounting problems mean Australia will fall well short of 2030 renewable energy target

image.altText: A Parramatta Eels NRLW player runs with the ball in two hands.

items.synopsis: Parramatta is hoping to kick-start its season when it hosts defending premier Newcastle. Later, the unbeaten Wests Tigers are on the road when they play Canberra. Follow our ScoreCentre for all the live scores and stats.

title.children: NRLW live: Eels clash with Knights as they chase first win of the season

image.altText: Donald Trump, holding an umbrella in the rain, speaks to reporters at an airport.

items.synopsis: US prosecutors flagged a threatening social media post from Donald Trump in a late-night court filing, arguing that it suggests he might intimidate witnesses by improperly disclosing confidential evidence received from the government.

title.children: 'IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!': Trump's social media post flagged by US prosecutors to judge

image.altText: Image of a metal sculpture of a man riding a horse.

items.synopsis: An art trail in outback Queensland is showcasing the work of local talent including the sculpture of a full-scale metal saddle bronc rider made from recycled horseshoes.

title.children: This impressive 500kg sculpture of a rodeo rider is made from discarded horseshoes

image.altText: Two middle-aged men in suits pose for a selfie in front of Sydney Harbour on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: With the WA government apparently backflipping on its Aboriginal Cultural Heritage laws, passed just a month ago, questions are being asked about whether new Premier Roger Cook has bowed to pressure from the PM, writes Cason Ho.

title.children: Did pressure from PM over Voice lead to controversial WA Juukan Gorge law being scrapped?

image.altText: Young Chinese boys play games on their phones.

items.synopsis: The Chinese government is considering making so-called "minor modes" mandatory on all mobile devices to limit the amount of time they can be used by young people. But some parents, children and experts think the restrictions don't address the real issues.

title.children: We asked Chinese parents and children what they thought of Beijing's plan to limit kids access to mobile devices

image.altText: A Kokatha woman with black hair pulled back wears a black shirt that reads 'Always' in gold and stands against wooden wall

items.synopsis: The first work by artistic director Frances Rings is a cautionary tale inspired by a precious, ancient water source hidden under the desert, which was drained dry and is now 'resting'.

title.children: Cautionary tale about ancient water source hidden beneath desert the subject of major new work
